intro: Gilia capitata subsp. abrotanifolia, commonly known as the Mexican gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its compact, bushy growth habit and produces showy clusters of bright red or orange flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its leaves are narrow and slightly hairy, providing a distinguishing feature. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens due to its vibrant blooms and drought tolerance.
